intro: Atalanthus quercifolius, commonly known as the oak-leaved false nettle, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant features palmate leaves resembling those of an oak tree, with lobed margins and a hairy texture. It produces small, pale yellow flowers arranged in clusters, followed by capsule fruits that release tiny seeds. The plant is often found in dry, rocky habitats and is adapted to thrive in arid conditions.
